normalised: Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control

unnormalised: Ranchi, Jharkhand – As Diwali approaches and demand for mithai and decorative items surges, manufacturers are doubling down on quality control measures. Experts at the National Institute of Technology (NIT) Jamshedpur are conducting workshops on Six Sigma methodologies for local SMEs to minimize defects in their production lines.

unnormalised: "Maintaining stringent quality standards is paramount, especially during peak seasons," says Dr. Priya Sharma, Head of Manufacturing at NIT Jamshedpur. "Imagine a batch of improperly sealed sweets or diya stands with cracks – that's unacceptable for Diwali celebrations."

unnormalised: These workshops emphasize statistical process control and root cause analysis, helping businesses like Krishna Enterprises (a candle manufacturer) and Lakshmi Foods (famous for their special Diwali barfi, priced at Rs. 500/kg) improve efficiency and reduce wastage. This translates to better products and happier customers. A recent survey indicates a 15% increase in customer satisfaction among companies who implemented these quality control protocols, proving its significant impact on the market. The goal is to deliver fault-free products, mirroring the perfection sought in every Onam sadhya.
